thread.title: Despite sprained MCL, ankle, Eagles' Lane Johnson 'definitely playing' vs. New Orleans Saints Sunday
thread.title_full: Despite sprained MCL, ankle, Eagles' Lane Johnson 'definitely playing' vs. New Orleans Saints Sunday

author: Matt Lombardo | For NJ Advance Media
title: Despite sprained MCL, ankle, Eagles' Lane Johnson 'definitely playing' vs. New Orleans Saints Sunday
text:
Despite sprained MCL, ankle, Eagles' Lane Johnson 'definitely playing' vs. New Orleans Saints Sunday Lane Johnson Philadelphia Eagles tackle Lane Johnson (65) is tended to by trainers on the field during the second half of an NFL football game against the Washington Redskins in Landover, Md., Sunday, Oct. 4, 2015. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky) (Patrick Semansky) 
PHILADELPHIA -- When Eagles right tackle Lane Johnson crumbled to the ground after a field goal try in the second half of Sunday's loss to the Washington Redskins at FedEx Field , he thought his season was over. 
"I felt a pop and I guess it was more my knee than my ankle, but I was scared," Johnson said following Tuesday's practice at the NovaCare Complex. "Usually if I'm on the ground ... And punching the ground, I thought I was done, to be honest. Fortunately it wasn't too bad." 
Johnson underwent an MRI Monday that revealed a sprained left MCL and sprained left ankle, but the former first round draft choice says he'll play Sunday vs. the New Orleans Saints despite missing Tuesday's practice. 
EAGLES VS. SAINTS: What makes Drew Brees elite? Bill Davis explains 
"Trying to get back to where I can practice later on in the week," Johnson said. "But I'll definitely be playing in the game. I'll be alright." 
The Oklahoma product has been wearing a brace on his knee all season that at times looks like it could be limiting his lateral movement and ability to block stunting defenders. However, Johnson credits the brace with saving his season. 
"If I wouldn't have had my brace on for that field goal, I think I would have blown my knee out," Johnson said. "It was pretty nasty. I think I'm just going to keep on wearing it. It isn't really effecting me, too much. It's keeping my knee intact. 
Despite his competitiveness and desire to be on the field, Johnson admitted that if the Eagles were fully healthy along the offensive line that he would consider taking more time to recover. THE NO-HUDDLE SHOW, Ep. 10: Can Chip Kelly fix the mess he's created with Eagles? 
We know Chip Kelly is a good coach, but after the Eagles' disastrous start to the season, we're starting to see he might not be a very good general manager. Subscribe to the podcast on iTunes or Stitcher .
